sub_topic: The construction of the Cantor set.
message_1: What is the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set obtained by removing the middle third of a line segment of length 1, then removing the middle thirds of the two line segments that remain, and so on?
message_2:
The Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set obtained by removing the middle third of a line segment of length 1, then removing the middle thirds of the two line segments that remain, and so on, can be calculated using the formula:

Hausdorff dimension (D) = log(N) / log(1 / r)

where N is the number of self-similar pieces and r is the scaling factor.

In the case of the Cantor set, after each iteration, there are N = 2 self-similar pieces, and the scaling factor is r = 1/3 (since we remove the middle third of each segment).

So, the Hausdorff dimension (D) is:

D = log(2) / log(1 / (1/3))
D = log(2) / log(3)

Therefore, the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set is approximately 0.6309.
